text: Solve this problem step by step.
End with 'DONE.' when you have a solution.
Question: A man lives on the 10th floor of an apartment building.
Every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
When he returns in the evening, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to reach his apartment.
However, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.

Why does he only take the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days? 

 Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I have this puzzle here about a man living on the 10th floor.
Let me try to figure out why he takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days.
Okay, every morning he takes the elevator down to the ground floor to go to work.
That makes sense because it's faster than walking up or down so many floors.
In the evening, when he returns, he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and then walks up the stairs for the remaining three floors to his apartment.

Hmm, why not go all the way up to the 10th floor on non-rainy days? 

Wait, on rainy days, he takes the elevator all the way to the 10th floor.
So, the difference is whether it's raining or not.
Maybe the elevator has some limitations? Let me think.
If the elevator can't go all the way to the 10th floor on non-rainy days, perhaps it's because of its design or the building's structure.
Maybe the elevator can only go up to the 7th floor normally.

But why would it be limited? 

Perhaps the elevator has a mechanical issue or a weight limit.
If it's too heavy, maybe it can't go beyond the 7th floor unless it's specifically allowed, like on rainy days.
Or maybe the building's elevator system is designed so that during rainy weather, the elevator can go higher, but on dry days, it's restricted.
Another angle: maybe the man is trying to save time or steps.
If he takes the elevator to the 7th floor and walks up three floors, he's saving himself from waiting for the elevator again if it's not going all the way.
But on rainy days, he doesn't mind taking the elevator all the way because maybe it's more convenient or efficient.

Wait, but why would the elevator be able to go higher only on rainy days? Is there something about the elevator's condition that changes with the weather? Or maybe the building has different elevator systems for different parts of the day or weather conditions.
Alternatively, maybe the man is trying to avoid taking the elevator when it's not needed, perhaps to save energy or because it's not convenient.
But on rainy days, he doesn't mind using the elevator fully.
I'm not sure.
Maybe the key is that the elevator can't go beyond the 7th floor on non-rainy days because it's broken or has a limit.
So, on rainy days, it's fixed or has more power, allowing it to go higher.
So, putting it all together, the man takes the elevator to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because the elevator is only functional up to the 7th floor.
On rainy days, it's working properly and can go all the way to the 10th floor, so he uses it.
Therefore, he only takes it to the 7th floor when it's not raining because that's as far as the elevator can go.

</think>

The man takes the elevator only to the 7th floor on non-rainy days because the elevator is limited to the 7th floor under normal conditions.
On rainy days, the elevator functions properly and can reach the 10th floor, allowing him to take it all the way up.
